questions.text: Preoxygenation is a very important initial step before giving general anesthesia. All of the following statements are correct about preoxygenation except

options.label: A
options.text: It is done to denitrogenate the patient

options.label: B
options.text: An alternative to preoxygenation is 3-4 vitals breaths with 100% oxygen

options.label: C
options.text: Preoxygenation can increase oxygen reserve for up to 20 minutes

questions.correct_answer: C. Preoxygenation can increase oxygen reserve for up to 20 minutes
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Preoxygenation can increase oxygen reserve for up to 20 minutes The main reserve of oxygen in the body is in the lungs in the form of functional residual capacity (FRC) which is 2.4 liters. An FRC filled with air has only 500 ml of oxygen (21% of 2.4 liters). Considering the oxygen consumption of the body to be 250 ml/minute, this oxygen will last only for 2 minutes. If 95% of the nitrogen in FRC is replaced with oxygen, 2.3 liters of FRC now is constituted of oxygen which the body can consume for 8-9 minutes

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Preoxygenation means giving 100% oxygen before induction of anesthesia. It replaces 95% of nitrogen in the lungs (denitrogenation) with oxygen thereby increasing the oxygen reserve of the body. So, the patient will be able to sustain hypoxia for longer periods in case the anesthetists is not able to intubate or not ventilate. Option: B. In case of life-saving emergencies where there is no time for preoxygenation an alternative method is to give 4 breaths of full vital capacity with 100% oxygen

questions.text: Most commonly used IV agent for induction
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Propofol Because of it’s shorter half-life, propofol is preferred for induction

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B . Thiopentone had been the preferred agent for induction before the availability of propofol however it is not preferred nowadays because of its long half-life of > 10 hours Option: C. Ketamine because of its side effect (mainly vivid reactions) is not a preferred agent in current-day practice Option: D. As there is a risk of adrenocortical suppression with etomidate, its use is restricted only for cardiac patients or vascular surgeries.

questions.text: Balanced anesthesia includes: Amnesia Analgesia Muscle relaxation Abolition of reflexes Select the correct answer from the below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1, 2, 3, and 4 are correct The basic triad of anesthesia is: Narcosis Analgesia Muscle relaxation In current-day practice our aim should be to achieve balance anesthesia which other than basic triad (narcosis, analgesia, and muscle relaxation) also includes amnesia, loss of reflexes, and maintenance of normal hemodynamics and homeostasis of the body.

Extraedge:

The concept of anesthesia was given by Oliver Wendell Holmes. The concept of balance anesthesia was given by John Lundy

questions.text: True about the stages of anesthesia:

options.label: C
options.text: Stage 2 is considered as surgical stage

questions.explanation:
Solution:

None of the above

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Stages of anesthesia were described by Guedel with Ether in 1920 Option: B. Guedel described 4 stages of anesthesia Option: C. Stage III is considered a stage of surgical anesthesia and the onset of stage III is best indicated by the onset of regular respiration. Stage 3 was further divided into 4 planes. Plane 3 is considered as the plane of choice because laryngeal reflexes go in this plane.

Extraedge:

To demarcate the stages of anesthesia the induction should be very slow. The inhalational agents now in use have fast induction. Therefore, these stages are not seen in current-day practice

questions.text: Arrange the following drugs in the sequence given in general anesthesia Propofol Suxamethonium Sevoflurane Atracurium Select the correct answer from the below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1, 2, 3, and 4 The sequence of GA Preoxygenation Induction- Induction is done with IV agents because they are ultrafast acting Suxamethonium- Given to relax muscles for intubation Maintenance of anesthesia- 75% N2O / Air + 25% oxygen + Volatile agent Surgical relaxation – provided with non-depolarizing muscle relaxants Reversal of effect of non-depolarizers- done with neostigmine Extubation
